display.name: $display
display.documentation: The `$display` system task displays its arguments in the same order as they appear in the argument list. It automatically adds a newline character to the end of its output.

display.name: $displayb
display.documentation: The `$displayb` system task displays its arguments in the same order as they appear in the argument list. It automatically adds a newline character to the end of its output. The output is formatted in binary.

display.name: $displayo
display.documentation: The `$displayo` system task displays its arguments in the same order as they appear in the argument list. It automatically adds a newline character to the end of its output. The output is formatted in octal.

display.name: $displayh
display.documentation: The `$displayh` system task displays its arguments in the same order as they appear in the argument list. It automatically adds a newline character to the end of its output. The output is formatted in hexadecimal.

display.name: $write
display.documentation: The `$write` system task displays its arguments in the same order as they appear in the argument list. It does not automatically add a newline character to the end of its output.

display.name: $writeb
display.documentation: The `$writeb` system task displays its arguments in the same order as they appear in the argument list. It does not automatically add a newline character to the end of its output. The output is formatted in binary.

display.name: $writeo
display.documentation: The `$writeo` system task displays its arguments in the same order as they appear in the argument list. It does not automatically add a newline character to the end of its output. The output is formatted in octal.

display.name: $writeh
display.documentation: The `$writeh` system task displays its arguments in the same order as they appear in the argument list. It does not automatically add a newline character to the end of its output. The output is formatted in hexadecimal.

display.name: $strobe
display.documentation: The `$strobe` system task provides the ability to display simulation data at a selected time. That time is the end of the current simulation time, when all the simulation events have occurred for that simulation time, just before simulation time is advanced.

display.name: $strobeb
display.documentation: The `$strobeb` system task provides the ability to display simulation data at a selected time. That time is the end of the current simulation time, when all the simulation events have occurred for that simulation time, just before simulation time is advanced. The output is formatted in binary.

display.name: $strobeo
display.documentation: The `$strobeo` system task provides the ability to display simulation data at a selected time. That time is the end of the current simulation time, when all the simulation events have occurred for that simulation time, just before simulation time is advanced. The output is formatted in octal.

display.name: $strobeh
display.documentation: The `$strobeh` system task provides the ability to display simulation data at a selected time. That time is the end of the current simulation time, when all the simulation events have occurred for that simulation time, just before simulation time is advanced. The output is formatted in hexadecimal.

display.name: $monitor
display.documentation: The `$monitor` system task provides the ability to monitor and display the values of any variables or expressions specified as arguments to the task.

display.name: $monitorb
display.documentation: The `$monitorb` system task provides the ability to monitor and display the values of any variables or expressions specified as arguments to the task. The output is formatted in binary.

display.name: $monitoro
display.documentation: The `$monitoro` system task provides the ability to monitor and display the values of any variables or expressions specified as arguments to the task. The output is formatted in octal.

display.name: $monitorh
display.documentation: The `$monitorh` system task provides the ability to monitor and display the values of any variables or expressions specified as arguments to the task. The output is formatted in hexadecimal.

display.name: $monitoron
display.documentation: The `$monitoron` system tasks control a monitor flag that enables and disables the monitoring. The `$monitoron` system task can be used to turn on the flag so that monitoring is enabled and the most recent call to `$monitor` can resume its display.

display.name: $monitoroff
display.documentation: The `$monitoroff` system tasks control a monitor flag that enables and disables the monitoring. Use `$monitoroff` to turn off the flag and disable monitoring.

file_io.name: $fopen
file_io.documentation: The `$fopen` system function opens the file specified as the *filename* argument and returns either a 32-bit multichannel descriptor or a 32-bit file descriptor, determined by the absence or presence of the *type* argument.

file_io.name: $fclose
file_io.documentation: The `$fclose` system task closes the file specified by *fd* or closes the file(s) specified by the multichannel descriptor *mcd*.

file_io.name: $fdisplay
file_io.documentation: The `$fdisplay` system task writes its arguments to specific files. It automatically adds a newline character to the end of its output.

file_io.name: $fdisplayb
file_io.documentation: The `$fdisplayb` system task writes its arguments to specific files. It automatically adds a newline character to the end of its output. The output is formatted in binary.

file_io.name: $fdisplayh
file_io.documentation: The `$fdisplayh` system task writes its arguments to specific files. It automatically adds a newline character to the end of its output. The output is formatted in hexadecimal.

file_io.name: $fdisplayo
file_io.documentation: The `$fdisplayo` system task writes its arguments to specific files. It automatically adds a newline character to the end of its output. The output is formatted in octal.

file_io.name: $fwrite
file_io.documentation: The `$fwrite` system task writes its arguments to specific files. It does not automatically add a newline character to the end of its output.

file_io.name: $fwriteb
file_io.documentation: The `$fwriteb` system task writes its arguments to specific files. It does not automatically add a newline character to the end of its output. The output is formatted in binary.

file_io.name: $fwriteh
file_io.documentation: The `$fwriteh` system task writes its arguments to specific files. It does not automatically add a newline character to the end of its output. The output is formatted in hexadecimal.

file_io.name: $fwriteo
file_io.documentation: The `$fwriteo` system task writes its arguments to specific files. It does not automatically add a newline character to the end of its output. The output is formatted in octal.

file_io.name: $fstrobe
file_io.documentation: The `$fstrobe` system task provides the ability to write simulation data at a selected time to specific files. That time is the end of the current simulation time, when all the simulation events have occurred for that simulation time, just before simulation time is advanced.

That time is the end of the current simulation time, when all the simulation events have occurred for that simulation time, just before simulation time is advanced. The output is formatted in binary.

file_io.documentation: The `$fstrobeh` system task provides the ability to write simulation data at a selected time to specific files. That time is the end of the current simulation time, when all the simulation events have occurred for that simulation time, just before simulation time is advanced. The output is formatted in hexadecimal.

file_io.name: $fstrobeo
file_io.documentation: The `$fstrobeo` system task provides the ability to write simulation data at a selected time to specific files. That time is the end of the current simulation time, when all the simulation events have occurred for that simulation time, just before simulation time is advanced. The output is formatted in octal.

file_io.name: $fmonitor
file_io.documentation: The `$fmonitor` system task provides the ability to monitor and write the values of any variables or expressions to specific files.

file_io.name: $fmonitorb
file_io.documentation: The `$fmonitorb` system task provides the ability to monitor and write the values of any variables or expressions to specific files. The output is formatted in binary.

file_io.name: $fmonitoro
file_io.documentation: The `$fmonitoro` system task provides the ability to monitor and write the values of any variables or expressions to specific files. The output is formatted in octal.

file_io.name: $fmonitorh
file_io.documentation: The `$fmonitorh` system task provides the ability to monitor and write the values of any variables or expressions to specific files. The output is formatted in hexadecimal.

file_io.name: $swrite
file_io.documentation: The `$swrite` system task writes its result string to the specified output variable.

file_io.name: $swriteb
file_io.documentation: The `$swriteb` system task writes its result string to the specified output variable. The output is formatted in binary.

file_io.name: $swriteo
file_io.documentation: The `$swriteo` system task writes its result string to the specified output variable. The output is formatted in octal.

file_io.name: $swriteh
file_io.documentation: The `$swriteh` system task writes its result string to the specified output variable. The output is formatted in hexadecimal.

file_io.name: $sformat
file_io.documentation: The `$sformat` system task is similar to the system task `$swrite`, with one major difference. Unlike the display and write family of output system tasks, `$sformat` always interprets its second argument, and only its second argument, as a format string.

file_io.name: $sformatf
file_io.documentation: The `$sformatf` system function behaves like `$sformat` except that the string result is passed back as the function result value for `$sformatf`, not placed in the first argument as for `$sformat`. Thus `$sformatf` can be used where a string value would be valid.

file_io.name: $fgetc
file_io.documentation: A single character can be read from a file using `$fgetc`.

file_io.name: $ungetc
file_io.documentation: `$ungetc` inserts the character specified by *c* into the buffer specified by file descriptor *fd*.

file_io.name: $fgets
file_io.documentation: One line can be read from a file using `$fgets`.

file_io.name: $fscanf
file_io.documentation: The `$fscanf` system function can be used to format data as it is read from a file.

file_io.name: $sscanf
file_io.documentation: The `$sscanf` system function can be used to format data as it is read from a string.

file_io.name: $fread
file_io.documentation: The `$fread` system function can be used to read binary data from a file.

file_io.name: $ftell
file_io.documentation: The `$ftell` system function is used to determine the current read or write position within a file.

file_io.name: $fseek
file_io.documentation: The `$fseek` system function can be used to change the current read or write position within a file.

file_io.name: $rewind
file_io.documentation: The `$rewind` system function can be used to change the current read or write position within a file. `$rewind` is equivalent to `$fseek (fd, 0, 0)`.

file_io.name: $fflush
file_io.documentation: The file I/O buffer can be flushed used `$fflush`.

file_io.name: $ferror
file_io.documentation: Should any error be detected by one of the file I/O routines, an error code is returned. Often this is sufficient for normal operation (i.e., if the opening of an optional configuration file fails, the application typically would simply continue using default values). However, sometimes it is useful to obtain more information about the error for correct application operation. In this case, the `$ferror` function can be used.

file_io.name: $feof
file_io.documentation: EOF can be tested for using `$feof`.

mem_load.name: $readmemb
mem_load.documentation: The `$readmemb` system task reads and loads data from a specified text file into a specified memory array.

mem_load.name: $readmemh
mem_load.documentation: The `$readmemh` system task reads and loads data from a specified text file into a specified memory array.

mem_dump.name: $writememb
mem_dump.documentation: The `$writememb` system task can be used to dump memory array contents to files that are readable by `$readmemb`.

mem_dump.name: $writememh
mem_dump.documentation: The `$writememh` system task can be used to dump memory array contents to files that are readable by `$readmemh`.

cmd_line.name: $test$plusargs
cmd_line.documentation: The `$test$plusargs` system function searches the list of *plusargs* for a user-specified *plusarg_string*.

cmd_line.name: $value$plusargs
cmd_line.documentation: The `$value$plusargs` system function searches the list of *plusargs* (like the `$test$plusargs` system function) for a user-specified *plusarg_string*.

vcd.name: $dumpfile
vcd.documentation: The `$dumpfile` system task is used to specify the name of the VCD file.

vcd.name: $dumpvars
vcd.documentation: The `$dumpvars` system task is used to list which variables to dump into the file specified by `$dumpfile`.

vcd.name: $dumpoff
vcd.documentation: The `$dumpoff` system task can be invoked to suspend the dump.

vcd.name: $dumpon
vcd.documentation: The `$dumpon` system task can be invoked to resume the dump.

vcd.name: $dumpall
vcd.documentation: The `$dumpall` system task creates a checkpoint in the VCD file that shows the current value of all selected variables.

vcd.name: $dumplimit
vcd.documentation: The `$dumplimit` system task can be used to set the size of the VCD file.

vcd.name: $dumpflush
vcd.documentation: The `$dumpflush` system task can be used to empty the VCD file buffer of the operating system to verify all the data in that buffer are stored in the VCD file.

vcd.name: $dumpports
vcd.documentation: The `$dumpports` system task is used to specify the name of the VCD file and the ports to be dumped.

vcd.name: $dumpportsoff
vcd.documentation: The `$dumpportsoff` and `$dumpportson` system tasks provide a means to control the simulation period for dumping port values.

vcd.name: $dumpportson
vcd.documentation: The `$dumpportsoff` and `$dumpportson` system tasks provide a means to control the simulation period for dumping port values.

vcd.name: $dumpportsall
vcd.documentation: The `$dumpportsall` system task creates a checkpoint in the VCD file that shows the value of all selected ports at that time in the simulation, regardless of whether the port values have changed since the last time step.

vcd.name: $dumpportslimit
vcd.documentation: The `$dumpportslimit` system task can be used to set the size of the VCD file.

vcd.name: $dumpportsflush
vcd.documentation: The `$dumpportsflush` system task writes all port values to the associated file, clearing a simulator’s VCD buffer.
